children.name: John Cournos
children.blurb: John Cournos was a Russian-born American writer who lived in London for a period. He probably met Sayers through the network of friends who lived at 44 Mecklenburgh Square, which was also briefly Sayers' address. Sayers and Cournos had a romantic relationship, which ended badly. They recounted the relationship in two separate novels, Strong Poison and The Devil is an English Gentleman. Cournos later married the American mystery writer Sybil Norton.

children.name: Atherton (Mac) Fleming
children.blurb: Atherton Mac Fleming was a journalist and gourmand. He and Sayers married in 1926.

children.name: Norman Davey
children.blurb: Norman Davey was a writer, the author of The Pilgrim of a Smile (1921). He and Sayers were friends in London.

children.name: Dorothy Scott Stokes
children.blurb: Dorothy Scott Stokes was a friend in London.

children.name: E.H.W. Meyerstein
children.blurb: E.H.W. Meyerstein was a poet. In June 1922, he visited Sayers at her flat and "read me 2000 odd lines of a mediaeval poem, which took him till 1 a.m. - me sitting sewing and listening, and feeling that tight feeling coming on all over my face! Still, it was quite a jolly poem."

children.name: Andrew Dakers
children.blurb: Andrew Dakers was Sayers' first agent, probably obtained through Cournos, whose agent he also was. He arranged the sale of the first Lord Peter books.

children.name: Mrs. Pendred
children.blurb: Mrs. Pendred was a friend during the early 1920s.

children.name: Bill White
children.blurb: Bill White was a motorcycle mechanic who introduced Sayers to the joys of riding motorbikes. They had a brief romantic relationship which resulted in Sayers' pregnancy.

children.name: Henry Sayers
children.blurb: Rev. Henry Sayers, Dorothy Sayers' father, was a Church of England clergyman who had parishes at St. Mary's, Bluntisham, in Cambridgeshire and at Christchurch in the Fens. He was the headmaster of Christ Church Choir School, in Oxford, when Dorothy was born. He began teaching his daughter Latin when she was only six years old, and he was the model for the gentle Rev. Theodore Venables in The Nine Tailors.

children.name: Helen (Leigh) Sayers
children.blurb: Helen (Leigh) Sayers was Dorothy Sayers' mother.

children.name: Robert Sayers
children.blurb: Rev. Robert Sayers was Dorothy Sayers' paternal grandfather.

children.name: Percival Leigh
children.blurb: Percival Leigh was Dorothy Sayers' maternal grandfather. He was a humorist, actor, and friend to novelists Dickens and Thackeray.

children.name: Mabel Leigh
children.blurb: Mabel Leigh was Dorothy Sayers' aunt.

children.name: Gertrude Sayers
children.blurb: Gertrude Sayers was Dorothy Sayers' aunt.

children.name: Henry Leigh
children.blurb: Henry Leigh was Dorothy Sayers' uncle, her mother's brother.

children.name: Maud Leigh
children.blurb: Maud Leigh was Dorothy Sayers' aunt, Henry Leigh's wife.

children.name: Ivy Shrimpton
children.blurb: Ivy Shrimpton was Dorothy Sayers's cousin. They were playmates and confidants as adolescents. Later, Ivy raised Dorothy's son, who was born out of wedlock in 1924.

children.name: Eleanor Sayers
children.blurb: Eleanor Sayers was Dorothy Sayers' elderly cousin.

children.name: Gerald Sayers
children.blurb: Gerald Sayers was Dorothy Sayers' cousin. They were at Oxford together.

children.name: John Anthony Fleming
children.blurb: John Anthony (White) Fleming was Sayers' son, born in January 1924. He was raised by Ivy Shrimpton and adopted legally by Mac Fleming. Sayers paid for his upbringing and became increasingly involved in his life as he got older, though she never disclosed his existence to her parents. Fleming attended Oxford (Balliol College).

children.name: Margaret Leigh
children.blurb: Margaret Leigh was Sayers' cousin and close contemporary.

children.name: Betty Osborne
children.blurb: Betty Osborne and Dorothy Sayers were childhood friends.

children.name: Eleanor Chase
children.blurb: Eleanor Chase was at the Godolphin School with Sayers.

children.name: Alice Chance Carleton
children.blurb: Alice Chance Carleton was a physician who specialized in dermatology and taught at Oxford. She and Sayers were friends.

children.name: Giles Dixey
children.blurb: Giles Dixey, the son of family friends, was at Oxford with Dorothy Sayers.

children.name: Frank Brabant
children.blurb: Frank Brabant, the son of family friends, was at Oxford with Dorothy Sayers.

children.name: Hugh Percy Allen
children.blurb: Dr. Hugh Percy Allen, the conductor of the Oxford Bach Choir, was the object of a youthful infatuation for Sayers. She was self-deprecating about her passion, however, and even impersonated him in her Going-Down Play.

children.name: Arthur Forrest
children.blurb: A talented musician, Arthur Forrest was at Oxford with Sayers. He fought in World War I and was killed at Dardanelles.

children.name: Leonard Hodgson
children.blurb: Rev. Leonard Hodgson met Sayers through Basil Blackwell. He proposed marriage to her repeatedly, but was rebuffed.

children.name: Basil Blackwell
children.blurb: Basil Blackwell ran a small publishing house on Broad Street in Oxford. He took Sayers on as an apprentice in 1917, and she worked for him until 1919. He also published her work in various forms at this time.

children.name: Roger Dixey
children.blurb: Roger Dixey was Giles' younger brother, the son of Sayers family friends. He served in World War I and suffered from shellshock.

children.name: Christine Blackwell
children.blurb: Christine Blackwell was Basil's wife; she became a friend of Sayers'.

children.name: Muriel (Jim) Jaeger
children.blurb: Muriel or Jim Jaeger was a writer. She and Sayers attended Somerville College together and maintained a friendship after going down. They almost lived together in London, but decided against it due to the vagaries of employment in the early postwar period. Her first novel, The Question Mark, was in the socialist utopian tradition, an answer to the unrealistic psychology of writers such as Wells and Bellamy.

children.name: Muriel St. Clare Byrne
children.blurb: Muriel St. Clare Byrne was a historian of the Tudor period. She and Sayers were lifelong friends and co-authored the play version of Busman's Honeymoon. She lived most of her life with Marjorie Barber.

children.name: Vera Brittain
children.blurb: Vera Brittain met Sayers at Somerville College just before the war. They both attended the ceremony at which Oxford granted its first degrees to women, in October 1920. Brittain mentions Sayers several times in her celebrated memoir, Testament of Youth.

children.name: Catherine (Tony) Godfrey
children.blurb: Catherine (Tony) Godfrey (later Mansfield) was at Somerville College with Dorothy Sayers. Sayers encouraged her writing and maintained a correspondence even after graduation, when both women became teachers for a time. She and Muriel Byrne wrote a history of Somerville College in 1921.

children.name: Elsie Henderson
children.blurb: Elsie Henderson was at Somerville College with Sayers. They travelled to France together in the summer of 1914, but their visit was cut short by the outbreak of war and Henderson's poor health.

children.name: Amphy Middlemore
children.blurb: Amphy Middlemore was at Somerville with Sayers.

children.name: Dorothy Rowe
children.blurb: Dorothy Rowe was at Somerville with Sayers.

children.name: Charis Barnett (Frankenburg)
children.blurb: Charis Barnett (Frankenburg) was at Somerville with Sayers. Her brother Donald was killed in World War I.

children.name: Doreen Wallace
children.blurb: Doreen Wallace was at Somerville with Sayers. She, too, fell in love with Eric Whelpton.

children.name: Winifred Holtby
children.blurb: Winifred Holtby was one of the Somerville novelists. She was Vera Brittain's close friend but also, apparently, a member of the Mutual Admiration Society writing group founded in part by Sayers.

children.name: Marjorie (Bar) Barber
children.blurb: Marjorie (Bar) Barber was at Somerville College. Later a lecturer in English, she was a friend of Sayers' and lived with Muriel St. Clare Byrne.

children.name: Florence (Jack) Barry
children.blurb: Florence (Jack) Barry was at Somerville with Sayers. She later got Sayers a temporary teaching position at Clapham High School.

children.name: Eric Whelpton
children.blurb: Eric Whelpton was born in France to English parents and served in World War I. He met Sayers when she was working in Oxford. He arranged for her to come work with him at an international educational bureau based in France at L'Ecole des Roches. There, Sayers' romantic interest in Whelpton became apparent; it was, unfortunately, not reciprocated.

children.name: Charles Crichton
children.blurb: Charles Crichton was a teacher at L'Ecole des Roches. His tales of upper-class life and of his loyal batman Bates may have provided raw material for Lord Peter Wimsey and Bunter.

children.name: Adele Camons
children.blurb: Ad√®le Camons was a servant at L'Ecole des Roches who became pregnant while unmarried. Sayers and Whelpton assisted her in finding a place to stay in Paris and in keeping the child.
